metadata.description:
The data set is NDVI data of long time series acquired by NOAA's Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) sensor. The time range of the data set is from 1982 to 2015. In order to remove the noise in NDVI data, maximum synthesis and multi-sensor contrast correction are carried out. A NDVI image is synthesized every half month. The data set is widely used in the analysis of long-term vegetation change trend. The data set is cut out from the global data set, so as to carry out the research and analysis of the source areas of the three rivers separately.
The data format of this data set is GeoTIFF with spatial resolution of 8 km and temporal resolution of 2 weeks, ranging from 1982 to 2015. Data transfer coefficient is 10000, NDVI = ND/10000.

background: The Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) derived from the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instruments has been crucial to study a variety of global land vegetation processes and how they vary in time. Although AVHRR sensors were not originally intended as a climate mission, their early success for vegetation studies was due to a reconfiguration of the instruments to have non-overlapping (“visible”) channel one (0.58–0.68 µm) and (near-infrared) channel two (0.725–1.10 µm) spectral bands. Since spectral vegetation indices are a surrogate for photosynthetic potential, the long record of AVHRR NDVI data has become particularly relevant for continued long-term monitoring of land surface. However, the difficulties in processing AVHRR NDVI data are to properly deal with several limitations of the AVHRR instrument or operation, e.g., vicarious post-launch calibration, atmospheric and cloud correction, and bias correction for the systematic orbital drift during the life of the individual TIROS-N missions. Among-instrument calibration is a prerequisite to observing and documenting the land variability and it is particularly challenging for the AVHRR because, by design, the instrument does not have fully onboard calibration for the visible and near-infrared (VNIR) channels and must rely on external references.
research objective: The goal of our work is to produce a consistent non-stationary NDVI data set to quantify climate-driven seasonal and inter-annual variability in photosynthetic capacity. In this paper, we show how to build a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset derived from AVHRR/2 and AVHRR/3 sensors based on Bayesian methods and the SeaWiFS NDVI dataset.
challenges: The main difficulty in processing AVHRR NDVI data is to properly deal with limitations of the AVHRR instruments. Complicating among-instrument AVHRR inter-calibration of channels one and two is the dual gain introduced in late 2000 on the AVHRR/3 instruments for both these channels. Orbital drift of the NOAA-7 to NOAA-14 satellites carrying AVHRR/2 instruments adds to the challenge since the NOAA satellite overpass times drifted from the nominal 1:30 pm overpass time by as much as 4.5 hours toward evening, creating variable illumination and view angles.
methods: We have processed NDVI data derived from the Sea-Viewing Wide Field-of-view Sensor (SeaWiFS) from 1997 to 2010 to overcome among-instrument AVHRR calibration difficulties. We use Bayesian methods with high quality well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data for deriving AVHRR NDVI calibration parameters.
dataset: The NDVI3g time series is an improved 8-km normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) data set produced from Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR) instruments that extends from 1981 to the present. The AVHRR instruments have flown or are flying on fourteen polar-orbiting meteorological satellites operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and are currently flying on two European Organization for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites (EUMETSAT) polar-orbiting meteorological satellites, MetOp-A and MetOp-B. This long AVHRR record is comprised of data from two different sensors: the AVHRR/2 instrument that spans July 1981 to November 2000 and the AVHRR/3 instrument that continues these measurements from November 2000 to the present.
findings: Evaluation of the uncertainties of our resulting NDVI values gives an error of ± 0.005 NDVI units for our 1981 to present data set that is independent of time within our AVHRR NDVI continuum and has resulted in a non-stationary climate data set.

Example.Answer: One method to address the challenge of orbital drift in satellite-based NDVI measurements is the use of Bayesian methods with high quality well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data to derive AVHRR NDVI calibration parameters, helping to mitigate the effects of variable illumination and view angles due to drift.

Example.Answer: An example of a technique used to improve consistency in NDVI data from different satellite sensors is the use of Bayesian methods to integrate AVHRR NDVI data with well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data, which helps overcome calibration difficulties among AVHRR instruments.

Definition.Question: What does 'vicarious post-launch calibration' mean in the context of AVHRR NDVI data collection?
Definition.Answer: Vicarious post-launch calibration refers to the process of adjusting satellite sensor data after launch by using external references or ground-based measurements to correct for any inaccuracies in the satellite's onboard calibration, ensuring that the data remains accurate over time.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for NDVI from AVHRR instruments compare to those using SeaWiFS sensors in terms of calibration challenges?
Comparison.Answer: NDVI data collection using AVHRR instruments faces challenges such as vicarious post-launch calibration and the lack of fully onboard calibration for visible and near-infrared channels, whereas SeaWiFS sensors provide high-quality well-calibrated NDVI data that can aid in deriving calibration parameters for AVHRR NDVI data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the NDVI3g dataset improve upon previous NDVI datasets derived from AVHRR instruments in terms of temporal coverage and error rates?
Comparison.Answer: The NDVI3g dataset provides an extended temporal coverage from 1981 to the present, with improvements in inter-instrument calibration and reduced error rates, boasting an uncertainty of ± 0.005 NDVI units that remains consistent over time. This marks a significant advancement over previous datasets, which may have lacked this level of consistency and accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred from the data processing techniques used to manage the calibration and correction challenges inherent in NDVI datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: To manage the calibration and correction challenges inherent in NDVI datasets, methodologies such as Bayesian methods are used to derive calibration parameters from well-calibrated datasets like SeaWiFS NDVI. This approach helps address calibration difficulties among AVHRR instruments and compensates for systematic biases introduced by the dual gain and orbital drift of the satellites.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges of AVHRR instruments influence the interpretation of long-term vegetation trends in NDVI datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges of AVHRR instruments, such as vicarious post-launch calibration, atmospheric and cloud correction, and bias correction for systematic orbital drift, influence the interpretation of long-term vegetation trends by necessitating careful calibration and correction processes to ensure data consistency and reliability. These challenges must be addressed to accurately quantify seasonal and inter-annual variability in photosynthetic capacity.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using multiple sensors over time for creating a consistent NDVI dataset and how does this affect data interpretation?
Interpretation.Answer: Using multiple sensors over time to create a consistent NDVI dataset implies the need for rigorous inter-calibration to ensure continuity in measuring land surface variability. This affects data interpretation by requiring advanced methods to handle variations introduced by different sensor designs and operational changes, ensuring that the NDVI data remains a reliable indicator of long-term vegetation dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for complex calibration techniques when processing NDVI data collected from AVHRR instruments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for complex calibration techniques arises due to several limitations of the AVHRR instruments, such as the lack of fully onboard calibration for visible and near-infrared channels, the dual gain introduced in AVHRR/3 instruments, and the systematic orbital drift of NOAA satellites, which leads to variable illumination and view angles.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the uncertainty in NDVI values derived from AVHRR data, and how are these uncertainties evaluated?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainties in NDVI values arise from the calibration challenges of AVHRR instruments, including post-launch calibration, atmospheric, and cloud corrections. These uncertainties are evaluated by analyzing the error margin in NDVI values, which is reported as ± 0.005 NDVI units across the dataset's temporal span.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using Bayesian methods for calibrating NDVI datasets derived from multiple sensors?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Bayesian methods for calibrating NDVI datasets allows for the derivation of calibration parameters from high-quality, well-calibrated datasets like SeaWiFS, helping to address inter-calibration challenges among AVHRR instruments and resulting in a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the impact of systematic orbital drift on the accuracy and reliability of NDVI data collected over time?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Systematic orbital drift can cause variable illumination and view angles due to shifts in satellite overpass times, potentially introducing biases in NDVI data, which necessitates bias correction to ensure accuracy and reliability over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the introduction of dual gain on AVHRR/3 instruments affect the calibration process for NDVI data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The introduction of dual gain on AVHRR/3 instruments complicates among-instrument calibration for channels one and two, making it challenging to achieve consistent calibration and requiring advanced techniques to overcome these limitations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals behind creating a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset from AVHRR sensors?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to produce a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset to quantify climate-driven seasonal and inter-annual variability in photosynthetic capacity.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to address the limitations of AVHRR instruments when processing NDVI data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main difficulty in processing AVHRR NDVI data is to properly deal with limitations of the AVHRR instruments, such as vicarious post-launch calibration, atmospheric and cloud correction, and bias correction for the systematic orbital drift during the life of the individual TIROS-N missions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of using Bayesian methods with SeaWiFS NDVI data in calibrating AVHRR NDVI data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Bayesian methods are used with high quality well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data to overcome among-instrument AVHRR calibration difficulties and derive AVHRR NDVI calibration parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures involved in calibrating NDVI data collected from AVHRR instruments to ensure consistency across different sensors?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To achieve a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset, Bayesian methods are used along with high-quality, well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data to derive calibration parameters for AVHRR NDVI. This approach addresses inter-calibration difficulties among AVHRR instruments due to dual gain settings introduced in AVHRR/3 and orbital drift affecting overpass times.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is noise reduction handled in NDVI data collected from the AVHRR sensors?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Noise reduction in AVHRR NDVI data is managed through techniques such as maximum value composites and multi-sensor comparison corrections. These processes are crucial to minimize noise and improve the reliability of the dataset for analyzing long-term vegetation trends.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in creating a long-term NDVI dataset for analyzing vegetation trends, especially considering the challenges presented by AVHRR instruments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To create a long-term NDVI dataset, challenges such as vicarious post-launch calibration, atmospheric and cloud correction, and bias correction for systematic orbital drift must be addressed. The process involves using well-calibrated datasets like SeaWiFS for reference and employing Bayesian methods to ensure consistency across different AVHRR sensors.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources are necessary to produce a consistent non-stationary NDVI data set for analyzing climate-driven seasonal and inter-annual variability?
Enablement.Answer: The production of a consistent non-stationary NDVI data set requires overcoming the limitations of AVHRR instruments, dealing with calibration issues, and processing NDVI data derived from other reliable sensors like SeaWiFS. Bayesian methods and high-quality, well-calibrated datasets are necessary to derive accurate calibration parameters.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of Bayesian methods and high-quality NDVI datasets from sensors like SeaWiFS enable improved calibration of AVHRR NDVI data?
Enablement.Answer: Bayesian methods, combined with high-quality NDVI datasets from sensors like SeaWiFS, enable improved calibration of AVHRR NDVI data by providing reliable calibration parameters that account for the limitations and calibration difficulties inherent in AVHRR instruments, such as dual gain and orbital drift challenges.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological approaches are essential to address the challenges of AVHRR instrument limitations and inter-calibration for accurate long-term vegetation monitoring?
Enablement.Answer: To address AVHRR instrument limitations and inter-calibration challenges, it is essential to use vicarious post-launch calibration, atmospheric and cloud correction, and bias correction for orbital drift. Additionally, leveraging high-quality datasets from other sensors and employing Bayesian methods are crucial for achieving accurate long-term vegetation monitoring.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise from the orbital drift of the NOAA satellites carrying AVHRR/2 instruments, and how do they affect data collection?
Expectation.Answer: The orbital drift of the NOAA-7 to NOAA-14 satellites carrying AVHRR/2 instruments causes overpass times to drift from the nominal 1:30 pm by as much as 4.5 hours toward evening, leading to variable illumination and view angles, which complicates data collection and requires correction for accurate NDVI measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to address limitations of the AVHRR instruments when processing NDVI data, and what are some of these limitations?
Expectation.Answer: It is important to address limitations such as vicarious post-launch calibration, atmospheric and cloud correction, and bias correction for systematic orbital drift to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the AVHRR NDVI data for long-term land variability observation. The lack of fully onboard calibration for VNIR channels also necessitates reliance on external references for proper calibration.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using Bayesian methods in overcoming the calibration challenges associated with AVHRR NDVI data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of Bayesian methods with high-quality, well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data is an effective approach to deriving AVHRR NDVI calibration parameters, as it addresses the among-instrument calibration difficulties and ensures the production of a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do you think the spatial and temporal resolutions of an NDVI dataset influence its suitability for analyzing vegetation trends in a specific region?
Judgmental.Answer: The spatial resolution of 8 km and temporal resolution of 2 weeks provide a balance that is suitable for analyzing long-term vegetation trends, as they allow for capturing regional variations while still maintaining sufficient detail to observe significant changes over time in a specific region like 三江源.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how datasets handling large temporal spans like this manage calibration challenges without onboard references.
Assertion.Answer: The datasets rely on external references for calibration, as the AVHRR instruments do not have onboard calibration for the visible and near-infrared channels. Bayesian methods are used with high-quality SeaWiFS NDVI data to derive calibration parameters, overcoming the calibration difficulties.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how consistent non-stationary NDVI datasets are built to reflect climate-driven variability in photosynthesis over long periods.
Assertion.Answer: Consistent non-stationary NDVI datasets are built using Bayesian methods to integrate data from AVHRR/2 and AVHRR/3 sensors, leveraging the SeaWiFS NDVI dataset for calibration. This approach enables the quantification of climate-driven seasonal and inter-annual variability in photosynthetic capacity.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a method for calibrating NDVI data derived from AVHRR sensors to ensure consistency and accuracy across different instruments and time periods.
Request/Directive.Answer: One method involves using Bayesian techniques with high-quality, well-calibrated SeaWiFS NDVI data to derive calibration parameters for AVHRR NDVI data. This approach addresses challenges such as among-instrument calibration difficulties and orbital drift, ensuring a consistent non-stationary NDVI dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could serve as a reference for improving the calibration of NDVI data collected by AVHRR instruments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include the Sea-Viewing Wide Field-of-view Sensor (SeaWiFS) NDVI data from 1997 to 2010, which offers high-quality and well-calibrated NDVI values that can be used to derive AVHRR NDVI calibration parameters, aiding in overcoming among-instrument calibration difficulties.
